Package runtime

Class SML_Simulator

java.lang.Object
runtime.SML_Simulator
public class SML_Simulator extends Object
A Simulator that executes commands to both compile a high-level-language program to machine code and to execute machine code. It defines the static method run which reads commands from standard in, interprets them and then executes them. The Simulator is stateless meaning that no information is stored between between 'run' sessions and that an instance of a Simulator is not necessary to run.

The 'run' process uses Requirements in order to specify different parameters. They can be obtained with the getRequriements() method, which contains more information about each individual Requirement.

Author:
Alex Mandelias

  • Method Details

    • main

      public static void main​(String[] args)
      Uses the command line arguments to specify the parameters necessary to compile and/or execute a program, and then compiles and/or executes it. Parameters starting with a single dash '-' are set to true. Parameters starting with a double dash '--' are set to whatever the next argument is.

      The different parameters are documented in the getRequirements() and getRequirements() methods.

      Parameters:
      args - the command line arguments

    • getRequirements

      public static requirement.util.Requirements getRequirements()
      Returns the Requirements needed for simulation. They have their default values and can be used as-is for simulation. 
       | Value   | Default | Explanation         | Command Line |
 |---------|---------|---------------------|--------------|
 | verbose | false   | output all messages | -            |
      Returns:
      the Requirements

    • run

      public static void run​(requirement.util.Requirements requirements)
      Uses the parameters from the requirements in order to repeatedly prompt the user for a command to execute, parse it, and then execute it.

      Information about the different commands the user may write can be found in the message which is optionally printed once at the start of simulation (only with -verbose flag) and may be printed again using the 'help' command.

      The different Requirements are documented in the getRequirements() method.

      Parameters:
      requirements - the parameters needed to compile
